displayed_text: Family Member: Right. Doctor: So it’s very common to see cancer cells along the nerves. Family Member: And the nerves came out with the vesicles? Doctor: Um hum. Family Member: Okay. Um is it any better that the extra prosthetic extension is a pattern three instead of a four? Doctor: Maybe. Family Member: I’m hoping. I’m looking for a little light of sunshine. Okay. And then the extra nodule that doesn’t say what that was. It just says it had extended out of one, the one positive node. Right? Doctor: So that’s not a ray of sunshine. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So node looks like that, actually they’re smaller. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And they can get cancer in them and then cancer can grow out of that a little bit. That’s extra nodule extension. Family Member: Um hum and you don’t know what that’s touching other nodes or other areas of the body?

Patient: Oh, ten isn’t climbing? Doctor: Yeah. Like, but if you’re fifty. That’s not in line with what I think is happening. You should level off with this stuff. Patient: Um hum. Family Member: It should come back down to like a seven or eight or whatever? Doctor: Yeah. Or even if it stays ten forever. I don’t care. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But I don’t want it to go to a hundred because then I’d feel like, uh-oh, maybe somethings going on. Family Member: Right. Doctor: You know? We, we have a look now which is not a super early look but it still is within, you know, a few weeks of finishing. Sometimes when times goes on, then, you know, you’ll have new stuff, but- Family Member: So no, no, no, uh, MRIs in order right now? Doctor: No. Unless you’re telling me you’re worse. Family Member: Well, he’s got, he’s in pain, but that might be sciatic. He don’t know. Patient: No.

Patient: Yes, yes. Doctor: So that’s perfect timing then. I’ll see you around the middle to the second half of January and we’ll check your PSA and your testosterone level at that point, about a week or two before. And I’ll give you a paper printout as well. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And hopefully the PSA will still be quite low at that point so we won’t have to take any action. You guys have any other questions you want to ask while we’re getting this done? Patient: No, No, the Lupron, yeah, yeah. Doctor: Perfect. Glad you’re continuing to do well. Again you look pretty well. Patient: Yeah. I feel great. It’s just the energy. Doctor: Yes. (keyboarding sounds) Patient: Wednesdays are fine. Doctor: That works better for you. Patient: Yes. But I’ll tell you it doesn’t matter. Whatever your schedule dictates. It doesn’t really matter. Doctor: Wednesday should be perfect.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So those were there even before you started the Xofigo. Patient: Right. Doctor: The radiation. Patient: Right. Doctor: So right now I think we will be in just watch and wait mode because I see no recompelling reason to put you on a new treatment. Patient: Okay, good. Family Member: So how will you know? Doctor: Well I think - Patient: Symptoms. Doctor: - both PSA and scans. We’ll probably plan on doing scans again in three months. Okay. Family Member: His last PSA do you have the results of that? Because we didn’t get uh… Where did you have that done?

Patient: Okay. So, the bloodwork I did today. What was that for? Doctor: That was for me to feel good about myself. No, uh. That was mostly looking at PSA. Patient: Again? Doctor: I think that – That was today’s blood. So. Family Member: So, they had a PSA. Patient: We did, we did. Doctor: No, no, what did you have today? Yeah. Well, I, I think that’s also part of this is getting me and the radiation folks together ‘cuz I think we’re ordering redundant now. I mean, they ordered a test; I ordered a test. You know, we’re, we need to kind of Patient: Okay. Doctor: Get one test, one doctor. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, you probably didn’t need to have another PSA test this soon, but we got one. Family Member: Okay. Well that’s fine.

Patient: So, the first thing is to, uh, see if I can come up (healthy) Doctor: Yeah. Just to see, yeah, how much it’s gonna cost ya. (Pause) Family Member: Okay. Patient: I think last time I was on the Xtandi, they wanted to know if I have any income to speak of or – Doctor: Yeah. They’ll do the wallet check and everything. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If they think you make enough money that you should be able to pay for it, then they’re not gonna give you one of these, uh, uh, grants. Patient: Yeah. (Pause) Doctor: Yeah. Okay. Family Member: Alright. Patient: With the Xtandi, the PSA still has to go up. Doctor: I’ll write that out for you what we’re lookin’ at. Okay? Patient: The ARV seven has to stay positive and, uh, (stuff)

Patient: Okay. Alright. Family Member: If he has non-cancer issues, he goes to him primary? Patient: Primary doctor, correct? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah, they’re smarter than us. Family Member: If he thinks he has a hernia, would that show on the CT scan? Would that be appropriate to send to the doctor? Doctor: No, because, yeah, the hernia, you know, when you’re laying down it really has to be pretty bad for it to be seen laying down. It’s usually when you’re standing up or sitting that it comes out. A hernia just means you have a weak area of muscle and then you have your bowel spill out. Typically, it doesn’t bother you unless it gets stuck, you know. Patient: Okay. Family Member: He’s having a lot of pain shooting up. Patient: Just I have a problem with my groin Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: I don’t know. The last one I had was in June. Doctor: Okay, I think you are so I’m gonna give this to J____ so we can just get everything on one paper because I don’t want to lose track of your next injection either. So, your Lupron stays in the background, we fart around with all this. Patient: Well, I took that in, Lupron and then all this. Doctor: In June or August? Oh, do I give you the Lupron? Oh, I don’t, Patient: No, Dr___ I had went to him in August. Doctor: okay. That’s why I don’t know, got it, yep. Patient: And I go back I think it’s in March. He gave me a six month shot this time. Doctor: Perfect. So, we will do the scans. I will see you back after you do the scan so it might be a week or two tops and then we’ll have a plan. In the meantime, I will have J____ start looking at your Provenge insurance so that we either know yes or no. We just need to know that, Patient: Okay. Doctor: okay, and then we’ll chat about what we see and we’ll get a plan. You’ve heard the kitchen sink now. Now we just have to pick one. Alright, I’ve got to make sure nobody else needs you for anything. Thank you Patient: Alright, thank you. Doctor: as always. Let me know about that leg too. Patient: Yeah. I got to say this only happened probably all that driving.

Patient: No, that's a, uh, a wart. I covered up. Doctor: Ok, alright. When did that thing--that wasn't there was it, last time? Patient: Well, it’s when cold weather hits it seems like to grow. Doctor: Oh you see, so you get these any way. Patient: Yeah, I go to the Dermanolog, Dermatologist for it. Doctor: Ok. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Alright, and uh, I do need to feel your tummy. (Dr. examining patient) Patient: Mm hmm. Doctor: And urine, no problems? Patient: No problems. Doctor: Ok. So should we go back on the chemo?

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um. I’m gonna put the prescription for the enzalutamide in our pharmacy, and they’re gonna do all the work behind the scenes to find out how much it’s gonna cost ya. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Put in the grants and all that other stuff for ya, so that we can get it. Once we know it’s a go, that’s when R_ and I will be back in touch about that. Okay? But you can always back out and say, “This doesn’t make sense. I’m not ready. He’s crazy. We’re not going back to Baltimore.” All of that. Okay? Something bad could happen. You could get in a lot of pain, and they got to treat you right then and there, and this will, will slip past you. Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But I hope that doesn’t happen. Patient: And even, even this treatment – is successful or just extend me for – Doctor: Yeah, I mean other diseases we’ve had people who, uh, their cancer doesn’t come back. Okay? But we haven’t seen that in prostate cancer. Patient: Ahhh. Doctor: Okay? Patient: I mean, I didn’t even have a prostate when I got it. How did that happen? Family Member: I don’t think they always got it all out of your lymph nodes when they first harvested it. Doctor: Yeah. It had to be there before they did the surgery.

Patient: So I should be good for three weeks anyway? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: I need some kind of release from you for our HR Department saying it’s okay for me to work. Doctor: Okay. Yeah. Patient: As long as I’m feeling up to it. Doctor: Okay. Yeah. We can fill one of those papers out. Yeah. Patient: Okay. What else did I have? Doctor: If you need to go upstairs, you can. Patient: You can go up and take care of it. Doctor: You’ve got to take care of business. Go ahead. You know we’ll be here a while. (Laughs) Family Member: I may have to go sign an order.

Patient: And will they give me the uh BET thing as part of the clinical trial? Doctor: Yeah, yeah that is part of it. Patient: So I’m in a new clinical trial basically. Doctor: Yes. Patient: And they’ll give me that as part of the clinical trial Doctor: Absolutely Patient: so no out-of-pocket for us? Doctor: Of gosh no that that you cannot get outside of the clinical trial. Patient: Really. Doctor: So you can’t get it if you tried. (Laughs) Patient: It’s so new. Uh and uh do you think within a month or two months we’ll know if it’s working? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah so I’m hoping to get you started within the next two or three weeks. Family Member: Oh yeah I mean we want to start right away.

Patient: Ow! Doctor: That’s the same (speaking softly) Patient: No. Patient: Awww. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: Okay so and you had quite a bit of this current chemotherapy that you’ve been on. Okay so we’ve given you about twelve cycles, but the good thing is it has worked and has kept the cancer in check all this time. The other good thing is that I didn’t see any other new areas. So the lung, liver, none of those were involved. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. So what I’m going to suggest is that we change to a different kind of chemotherapy. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because the advantage is that you know this mass that is resistant to the current chemotherapy will hopefully… Patient: Do you think that, you think that… Doctor: Respond. Patient: Okay. Nah you can keep Dr. V____.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: But we need to uh see if the testosterone is not right then I need… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …to get that authorized. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Alright. Doctor: Alright so I don’t think anything else except we’ll wait and see. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But we’ll be in touch once we know. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.10 or more times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::10 or more times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.strongly disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.::: strongly disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.strongly disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.::: strongly disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.strongly disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::strongly agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::strongly agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.strongly agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::strongly agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Prefer to self-describe (please specify): What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Prefer to self-describe (please specify)

displayed_text: Family Member: So how are you feeling about how he is doing? Patient: Disappointed. Doctor: …this is a slight set back that Xtandi didn’t last us as long as I had hoped it would. And honestly I don’t know if that is part of the sort of resistance of BRC - BRCA mutant disease or not. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Nobody does really at this point because very few people have been really treated with Xtandi up front like that. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So I think that is something to track down obviously, but um we’ll have to see how it goes. I’m just hoping you know we definitely have the Lynparza sort of as a fall back. Um again- Patient: So I’d be two steps away from chemo. Doctor: But getting that as well not quite and who knows how many more steps we’ll find as we go along, you know. Like I said this BET inhibitor wasn’t there what six months ago if you had needed this option and it wasn’t there for you. So it’s changed very rapidly. Patient: Everything is brand new. Doctor: Yeah but obviously we should jump on that if we can. Patient: And will they give me the uh BET thing as part of the clinical trial?
